name: Avraham Avinu | Jewish Heroes
description: Abraham (Avraham Avinu - 'Our Father Abraham') is the foundational patriarch of Israel and the father of the covenant people. God called him from Ur of the Chaldeans to journey to an unknown land, establishing through him an everlasting covenant marked by circumcision and sealed with unconditional promises. Through Abraham's seed, all nations of the earth would be blessed - a promise Matthew's Gospel shows fulfilled in Jesus Christ. Abraham's willingness to sacrifice Isaac (the Akedah) on Mount Moriah prefigures God's sacrifice of His own Son. Matthew opens his Gospel with 'The book of the genealogy of Jesus Christ, the son of David, the son of Abraham' (Matthew 1:1), placing Jesus squarely within Abraham's covenant line. Abraham believed God, and it was credited to him as righteousness - establishing the pattern of justification by faith that runs through Scripture from Genesis to Revelation.

petrinePerspective.description: Peter's understanding of Abraham as father of the covenant people and channel of blessing to all nations

acts3Sermon.context: In Solomon's Porch after healing the lame man at the Beautiful Gate, Peter explicitly connected Jesus to the Abrahamic covenant
acts3Sermon.quotation: Ye are the children of the prophets, and of the covenant which God made with our fathers, saying unto Abraham, And in thy seed shall all the kindreds of the earth be blessed. Unto you first God, having raised up his Son Jesus, sent him to bless you, in turning away every one of you from his iniquities. (Acts 3:25-26)
acts3Sermon.theologicalImplication: Peter identifies Jesus as the promised 'seed' of Abraham through whom all nations receive blessing

gentileInclusion.corneliusVision: Peter's vision of clean and unclean animals (Acts 10) prepared him to understand that Abraham's blessing extended to Gentiles
gentileInclusion.acts10Realization: Peter declared: 'Of a truth I perceive that God is no respecter of persons: But in every nation he that feareth him, and worketh righteousness, is accepted with him' (Acts 10:34-35)
gentileInclusion.fulfillmentOfPromise: When Gentiles received the Holy Spirit (Acts 10:44-48), Peter recognized this as the extension of Abraham's blessing to 'all kindreds of the earth'

jerusalemCouncil.context: At the Jerusalem Council (Acts 15), Peter defended Gentile inclusion without full Torah observance
jerusalemCouncil.argument: Peter recalled that God gave Gentiles the Holy Spirit 'even as he did unto us' (Acts 15:8), confirming they were included in Abraham's blessing through faith

gentileInclusionTheme.originalPromise: In thee shall all families of the earth be blessed (Genesis 12:3)
gentileInclusionTheme.renewedPromise: In thy seed shall all the nations of the earth be blessed (Genesis 22:18)
gentileInclusionTheme.paulineInterpretation: And the scripture, foreseeing that God would justify the heathen through faith, preached before the gospel unto Abraham, saying, In thee shall all nations be blessed (Galatians 3:8)
gentileInclusionTheme.petrineApplication: Peter's vision of clean and unclean animals (Acts 10) revealed that the Abrahamic promise of blessing to all nations was being fulfilled through Christ and the Gospel going to the Gentiles
gentileInclusionTheme.connectionToCornelius: The Holy Spirit falling on Cornelius's household (Acts 10:44-48) demonstrated that Gentiles were truly included in Abraham's covenant blessing through faith in Christ
